p:
Longitudinal studies of wild populations provide the opportunity to determine whether phenotypic changes are adaptive (e.g. refs.
7– 9 ). A phenotypic change qualifies as an adaptive response to climate change if three conditions are met: (1) a climatic factor changes over time, (2) this climatic factor affects a phenotypic trait of a species and (3) the corresponding trait change confers fitness benefits (Fig. 1)
10, 11 . These conditions are usually assessed in isolation
11– 14 (but see, for example, refs.
7, 8 ) and hence most studies can only speculate on whether adaptive responses have occurred. Here, we extracted data from many published studies to assess these three conditions in free-living animals and thus determine whether the observed phenotypic changes are adaptive.
